questions.text: Match the ligament with its functions:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Each ligament plays a distinct role in maintaining the stability and arch of the foot.

Plantar fascia ligament: This thick band of connective tissue runs from the calcaneus to the toes, helping maintain the longitudinal arch and absorb shock during walking.

Plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (Spring ligament): Located beneath the head of the talus, this ligament supports the medial longitudinal arch and is crucial for arch structure and weight-bearing.

Calcaneocuboid ligament: It connects the heel (calcaneus) to the cuboid bone, helping stabilize the lateral part of the foot and maintain the arch.

Lisfranc ligaments: Located in the midfoot, they stabilize the connection between metatarsals and tarsal bones, particularly beneath the Lisfranc joint.

questions.text: Which of the following ligament is responsible for injury shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The spring ligament (plantar calcaneonavicular ligament) supports the head of the talus and medial longitudinal arch, its injury leads to arch collapse.

  • The spring ligament stretches from the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone, forming a sling beneath the talar head.
  • It is a key stabilizer of the medial longitudinal arch and supports the talus during weight-bearing.
  • When the spring ligament is torn or weakened, it can no longer support the talar head properly, leading to medial arch collapse, flatfoot deformity, and talar head protrusion, as seen in the image.

Explanation of other options:

Calcaneocuboid ligament (Option B): Supports the lateral arch of the foot, not involved in medial arch or talar head support.

Lisfranc ligament (Option C): Connects medial cuneiform to second metatarsal, stabilizes midfoot joints, not the medial arch or talar head.

Plantar fascia ligament (Option D): Supports the longitudinal arch but lies more superficial and is rarely the primary ligament in talar displacement.

questions.text: What is not true about the Chopart ligament?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Chopart ligament (bifurcate ligament) is not part of the calcaneonavicular ligament; it is a distinct structure composed of calcaneonavicular and calcaneocuboid bands.

  • The Chopart ligament, commonly referred to as the bifurcate ligament, is a Y-shaped ligament arising from the anterior dorsal surface of the calcaneus.
  • It splits into:
    • Calcaneonavicular part
    • Calcaneocuboid part
  • It plays a crucial role in stabilizing the Chopart joint (transverse tarsal joint), which includes the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints.
  • The spring ligament, not the Chopart ligament, is classically referred to as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament and is involved in arch support; This is often confused with the bifurcate ligament due to similar sounding names.
